PROJECT MGZ

Seamlessly blending vintage charm with modern power, delivering an exhilarating, nostalgia-filled driving experience that will leave you smiling from ear to ear.

DISCOVER MORE

HISTORY

The MGB is a beloved classic known for its charm and character, but when it comes to raw power and speed, it often falls short of modern expectations. Enter Project MGZ, a labor of love undertaken by the father-son team of Jack and Brian Collins at Ceres Motorsports in Oviedo, Florida. Their mission was clear: transform a 1979 MGB into a spirited modern classic while retaining the essence of the original.

In September 2012, the Collins duo discovered a 1979 MGB roadster on Craigslist that would become the canvas for their ambitious project. The car had led a gentle life, with just 43,000 miles on the odometer and a history of only two previous owners. This MGB was well-preserved, having spent most of its days sheltered from the elements. Despite being stored in a garage, the car started and idled easily. Brian purchased the car and was able to drive it home to look over its mechanical condition. To infuse the MGB with newfound vigor, the Collinses sought a modern engine and transmission combination that would complement the car's size and weight while preserving its character. The choice fell on the Ford Zetec engine, a compact and affordable powerplant with robust aftermarket support.

They acquired a 2.0-liter DOHC 16-valve engine from a 2003 Ford Focus ZX3. In its stock configuration, this engine produced around 130 horsepower, but with extensive modifications and aftermarket upgrades, it had the potential to generate a thrilling 185 horsepower. This power output promised excitement in a car that weighed less than 2,000 pounds.

One of the most significant challenges of this engine swap was adapting the transverse Ford Zetec engine, originally designed for front-wheel-drive applications, to a rear-wheel-drive setup in the MGB. To make this ambitious conversion possible, the Collins team had to modify the bellhousing and the input shaft of a Tremec T-5 transmission, a critical step in marrying the engine and gearbox.

To ensure optimal fuel and air intake, a custom-made intake manifold was crafted to accommodate a set of carburetors sourced from a Kawasaki ZX9R sportbike. Ignition was expertly managed through a combination of a crank position sensor, Ford EDIS module, and a Megajolt Lite Jr. Ignition Module. The cooling system, now positioned at the rear of the car in a longitudinal configuration, required the fabrication of a custom thermostat neck and tubing to redirect coolant to the front.

Project MGZ wasn't just about the powertrain. The team made additional enhancements to achieve a cohesive blend of classic aesthetics and modern performance. They converted the car to chrome bumpers and adorned it with a stunning Blue Royale paint, a stock color available in 1970. To optimize handling, the MGB was lowered by 1.5 inches in the front and 1 inch in the rear.

The finishing touch came with the installation of 15-inch Ceres Steelies, allowing the fitment of high-performance BF Goodrich Sport Comp 2 tires. These upgrades improved traction, ensuring that the newfound power could be effectively harnessed.

After countless hours of meticulous work, Project MGZ was realized. The MGB, now transformed into a modern classic, embodied the spirit of the original while delivering exhilarating performance. With its 185-horsepower Zetec engine, custom bodywork, and a sleek Blue Royale finish, the car was a head-turner on the road.

The Collins duo clocked over 10,000 miles in their creation, taking it to numerous shows and events, where it consistently garnered attention and admiration. The MGZ project exceeded their expectations, offering both the charm of a classic and the thrill of a modern sports car. Most importantly, it no longer left oil stains on the garage floor, a newfound reliability in the world of vintage British automobiles.

Project MGZ is a testament to the transformative power of creativity, expertise, and passion. It's a reminder that classic cars can evolve, gaining modern performance without sacrificing their timeless appeal. As the Collins team at Ceres Motorsports continues their journey, one thing is clear: Project MGZ won't be their last remarkable creation.

SPECIFICATIONS

Project MGZ beautifully marries the classic MGB DNA with carefully chosen upgrades and enhancements designed to elevate the driving experience. While many of the original MGB components have been retained, simplifying maintenance and repairs for enthusiasts, specific elements have been thoughtfully updated and replaced to enhance both performance and reliability.

HIGHLIGHTED UPGRADES:

ENGINE:

  • 2003 DOHC Ford 2.0 Zetec Engine
  • Fully Ported Cylinder Head
  • Comp Cams Stage 2 Camshafts
  • Fidanza Adjustable Cam Gears
  • Kawasaki ZX9R Carburetors
  • Custom fabricated air intake with K&N Air Filter
  • Mac Shorty Exhaust Header
  • Modified Stainless Tourist Trophy Sport Exhaust

DRIVETRAIN:

  • 1998 Mustang V6 T5 w/3.35 first gear
  • Custom Driveshaft
  • Modified 15"x6" Steel Wheels
  • 196/55R15 BFGoodrich Sport Comp 2 Tires

IGNITION:

  • Ford EDIS4 with Megajolt Lite Jr. Ignition Controller
  • Screamin' Demon Coilpack
  • Taylor ThunderVolt 8.2mm Spark Plug Wires
  • Motorcraft Copper Spark Plugs

COOLING SYSTEM:

  • Ford Mustang Aluminum Radiator with 16" Electric Fan

ELECTRICAL:

  • GM CS130 Alternator
  • Exterior and Interior LED Lights

MEDIA

    • Engine Swap Depot also feature Project MGZ, providing a few more details about the components used in the engine swap..

    • Ford Authority wrote an article based on the coverage from Classic Motorsports.
